GL with learning Rust! I nearly finished the Rust Book, I really liked it, I had, like never before, a really strong feeling that some people really put thoughts into everything. Also, it doesn‚Äôt suffer from some past debt (like the null-mistake) as some other languages. It also mostly takes slightly different approaches to some common concepts like async, but in a good way, as well as some other nice things like zero-cost abstractions i.e. with .iter(). So, if you really want to learn it, I hope you don‚Äôt regret this decision in some years and maybe have same feeling :-)

This looks like a cool project! If you‚Äôd like it to look a little more polished, you might want to consider using ANSI escape codes to clear the screen before showing the screen every time. Not sure how it works in Rust but in TypeScript (or JavaScript) it‚Äôs console.log("\x1b[2J\x1b[H") the \x1b  means 1b in hexadecimal, 2J means clear screen, H means start outputting at top left. Even if this doesn‚Äôt help, good luck, it looks nice!

However, if you type ‚Äú:!‚Äú in Vim, you can run terminal commands like you suggested! I‚Äôll try to implement those too‚Ä¶And yeah. what are you bitonic sorting for????
move ordering was rly slow with linear sorting from before and i‚Äôm looking at other ways to do it faster  it might not be worth the overhead so uh we‚Äôll see once i implement it

the current idea is to split the move sets into a bitonic part and a regular linear tail, where the majority of the moves gets ordered more quickly, and merge the two sections later (to hopefully make moveordering faster)

i implemented simd a while back while not understanding the whole thing so when it looked like it worked i didn‚Äôt check it but uh now that timings got added for uci as per previous devlogs i was wondering why the best move wasn‚Äôt getting searched, turns out it wasn‚Äôt ordered as the first move so hence it led me to discover the simd i had a few weeks back doesn‚Äôt actually work

there‚Äôs no way move ordering sorting is the holdup‚Ä¶.. also i think the traditional way to do this is just selection sort (just getting the max score out of remaining moves) because with proper sorting/pruning techniques most of the time you‚Äôll only be getting a handful of moves so sorting the rest is wasted work (is this what bitonic sort does? idk what it does.) if you want to look into more of thsi style the other main optimization i‚Äôve heard of is staged movegen but its cursed imo

bitonic is optimized for parallel CPU operations so it does all of the comparisons at once, with few iterations depending on data size, especially optimized with vectors and simd intrinsics. It only takes powers of 2‚Äôs amounts of inputs at one go (2,4,8,16 etc number of elems) and it‚Äôs faster bc of the parallelization.   insertion sort is what i had before i believe, and is still what i use for the tail bit that doesn‚Äôt fit into the biggest pow2 there is possible for the moveset, and yeah i also looked into some stuff and was rly considering just not sorting the stuff after the top 5 or so moves, but bitonic seemed to promise performance while sorting the entire thing (although idk how much overhead it will have and impact actual gameplay), gonna do a bunch of testing probs
fwiw in my engine i just did a profile, the move selector is 1.5% of total runtime

I was thinking of using MySQL for storage however I dropped that idea since this was meant to be used as a simple locally hosted chat app with temporary chat rooms.  I know that this also means that a person joining late would be unable to see previous messages but this is intentional by design. I must say that I disagree with your take on vibe coding ‚Äî especially the argument of ‚ÄúCameras on Phones didn't kill professional photographers‚Äù.. what ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù does is making creativity a commodity, essentially. It‚Äôs not like an IDE helping you autocomplete functions or check for grammar rules. It‚Äôs just writing everything for you. There was a quote, ‚ÄúWe shape our tools and our tools shape us.‚Äù In this way, I think we‚Äôre letting these tools shape us too much, if we‚Äôre giving up creativity and passion for efficiency. It‚Äôs a bit dystopian.

I mean, if someone doesn‚Äôt have the skillset or time to make a website, why not just use Wix or wordpress (or a similar drag-and-drop?) We don‚Äôt have to put up a front, and pretend we‚Äôre good at anything‚Ä¶   Well, non-philosophically,  I‚Äôm very genuinely hoping that you DID AI-generate some of these docs (it reads a little bit that way). From my experience with chatting with an AI, managing React & database stuff is an absolute nightmare. The systems get pretty complicated fast, especially the more niche something is. Granted, I was talking to GPT, idk how your experience with Cursor is.    If you‚Äôve ever looked at someone else‚Äôs code before, you‚Äôll probably understand the feeling of just fundamentally not understanding their structure. Uh, I guess that‚Äôs how I feel about AI code a lot of the time. I do feel kinda strongly about this topic. Anyway, I‚Äôd be open to any of your thoughts on it! (hopefully not AI generated thoughts, as those tend to be quite repetitive)
